chunk: Hemoglobin is a protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen. Low levels may indicate anemia. Reference range: 12 - 15 g/dL.
Hematocrit is the percentage of blood volume occupied by red blood cells. Low levels can indicate anemia. Reference range: 36 - 46%.
RBC (Red Blood Cell) count measures how many red blood cells you have. It helps assess oxygen transport. Reference range: 3.9 - 5.2 million/cumm.
WBC (White Blood Cell) count measures the number of white blood cells in your blood. It helps fight infection. Reference range: 4,000 - 11,000 cells/cumm.
Platelets are cells that help your blood clot. Low counts may cause excessive bleeding or bruising. Reference range: 150,000 - 400,000 /μL.
MCV (Mean Corpuscular Volume) indicates the average size of your red blood cells. It helps diagnose anemia types. Reference range: 80 - 100 fL.
MCH (Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin) is the average amount of hemoglobin per red blood cell. Reference range: 12 - 15 g/dL.
MCHC (Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin Concentration) measures the concentration of hemoglobin in red blood cells. Reference range: 12 - 15 g/dL.
RDW (Red Cell Distribution Width) measures variation in red blood cell size. High RDW may indicate anemia. Reference range: 11.5 - 14.5%.
Neutrophils are a type of white blood cell that fight bacterial infections. High levels may indicate infection. Reference range: 40 - 80%.
Lymphocytes are white blood cells that play a key role in your immune system. Low levels can indicate immune issues. Reference range: 20 - 40%.
Monocytes are white blood cells that help break down bacteria. Elevated levels can suggest inflammation. Reference range: 2 - 10%.
Eosinophils help fight allergies and parasitic infections. Reference range: 1 - 6%.
Basophils are the least common type of WBC but are involved in allergic reactions. Reference range: 4,000 - 11,000 cells/cumm.
Total Cholesterol measures all cholesterol in your blood. High levels increase heart disease risk. Reference range: < 200 mg/dL.
HDL (High-Density Lipoprotein) is the 'good' cholesterol. Higher levels are better for heart health. Reference range: > 40 mg/dL.
LDL (Low-Density Lipoprotein) is the 'bad' cholesterol. High levels increase heart disease risk. Reference range: < 100 mg/dL.
VLDL (Very Low-Density Lipoprotein) carries triglycerides. High levels can contribute to heart disease. Reference range: < 100 mg/dL.
Triglycerides are a type of fat in the blood. Elevated levels are a risk factor for heart disease. Reference range: < 150 mg/dL.
CHOL/HDL Ratio is used to estimate heart disease risk. A lower ratio is generally better. Reference range: > 40 mg/dL.
LDL/HDL Ratio compares bad to good cholesterol. Higher values indicate more risk. Reference range: > 40 mg/dL.
Sodium helps regulate fluids and nerve function. Imbalances can cause confusion or seizures. Reference range: 135 - 145 mEq/L.
Potassium is critical for heart and muscle function. Too high or low can be dangerous. Reference range: 3.5 - 5.0 mEq/L.
Chloride helps maintain fluid balance and blood pressure. Reference range: 98 - 107 mEq/L.
Bicarbonate helps regulate blood pH balance. Reference range: 22 - 29 mEq/L.
BUN (Blood Urea Nitrogen) measures kidney function. Elevated levels may indicate kidney problems. Reference range: 7 - 20 mg/dL.
Creatinine is a waste product measured to assess kidney function. Reference range: 0.6 - 1.2 mg/dL.
eGFR estimates how well your kidneys are filtering blood. Lower values indicate worse function. Reference range: > 60 mL/min/1.73m².
Glucose measures blood sugar. It is used to screen for and manage diabetes. Reference range: 70 - 99 mg/dL (fasting).
HbA1c reflects average blood sugar over the past 3 months. It is used to diagnose and monitor diabetes. Reference range: < 5.7%.
ALT (Alanine Aminotransferase) is a liver enzyme. High levels can indicate liver damage. Reference range: 7 - 56 U/L.
AST (Aspartate Aminotransferase) is a liver enzyme. It's often tested with ALT. Reference range: 7 - 56 U/L.
ALP (Alkaline Phosphatase) is an enzyme related to bile ducts. High levels may suggest liver or bone issues. Reference range: 44 - 147 IU/L.
Bilirubin is a pigment processed by the liver. High levels may cause jaundice. Reference range: 0.1 - 1.2 mg/dL.
Albumin is a protein made by the liver. Low levels can indicate liver or kidney problems. Reference range: 3.5 - 5.5 g/dL.
Total Protein measures all proteins in blood. Abnormal levels can reflect liver or nutritional issues.
CRP (C-Reactive Protein) is a marker of inflammation. High levels can indicate infection or chronic disease. Reference range: < 3 mg/L.
ESR (Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate) is a nonspecific marker of inflammation. Reference range: 0 - 20 mm/hr.
Ferritin reflects stored iron in the body. Low levels may indicate iron deficiency. Reference range: 12 - 300 ng/mL.
Vitamin D helps with calcium absorption and bone health. Low levels can lead to bone problems. Reference range: 7 - 56 U/L.
Vitamin B12 is vital for nerves and blood cell production. Deficiency may cause fatigue or neuropathy. Reference range: 190 - 950 pg/mL.
Folate is essential for DNA synthesis and red blood cell production. Reference range: 2.7 - 17.0 ng/mL.
Calcium supports bones, teeth, muscles, and nerves. Reference range: 8.5 - 10.2 mg/dL.
Phosphorus helps build bones and is involved in energy metabolism. Reference range: 2.5 - 4.5 mg/dL.
Magnesium is involved in muscle, nerve, and enzyme function. Reference range: 1.7 - 2.2 mg/dL.
Iron is needed for red blood cell production. Low levels lead to anemia. Reference range: 60 - 170 mcg/dL.
TSH (Thyroid Stimulating Hormone) controls thyroid hormone production. High or low levels indicate thyroid problems. Reference range: 0.4 - 4.0 μIU/mL.
T3 (Triiodothyronine) is a thyroid hormone affecting metabolism. Reference range: 80 - 200 ng/dL.
T4 (Thyroxine) is a key hormone regulating metabolism and energy. Reference range: 5.0 - 12.0 μg/dL.
Testosterone is a hormone important for sexual function and muscle mass. Reference range: 300 - 1000 ng/dL.
FSH (Follicle Stimulating Hormone) regulates reproductive processes. Reference range: 3 - 10 mIU/mL.
LH (Luteinizing Hormone) helps regulate ovulation and testosterone. Reference range: 300 - 1000 ng/dL.
Cortisol is a stress hormone that affects metabolism and immune response. Reference range: 6 - 23 mcg/dL.
Insulin controls blood sugar levels. Abnormal levels are linked to diabetes. Reference range: 2 - 20 μIU/mL.
D-Dimer is a protein fragment from blood clots. High levels suggest clotting problems. Reference range: < 0.5 μg/mL.
Procalcitonin is a marker of bacterial infection and sepsis. Reference range: < 0.1 ng/mL.
Troponin is released when the heart muscle is damaged. High levels suggest a heart attack. Reference range: < 0.04 ng/mL.
BNP (Brain Natriuretic Peptide) is elevated in heart failure. Reference range: < 100 pg/mL.
NT-proBNP helps diagnose and monitor heart failure. Reference range: < 100 pg/mL.
ANA (Antinuclear Antibody) is used to detect autoimmune diseases like lupus.
HIV tests detect the human immunodeficiency virus.
Hepatitis B tests detect viral infection affecting the liver.
Hepatitis C tests check for chronic liver infection.
